nodes.bodyText: Method hasReachedMaxUnitBuiltPerPlayer has a Cognitive Complexity of 11 (exceeds 5 allowed). Consider refactoring.

Method findMaxConstructionTypeAllowed has a Cognitive Complexity of 8 (exceeds 5 allowed). Consider refactoring.

Is this comment now misplaced? It's hard to see how it relates to the next couple lines, seems like it relates to lines below it.
The comment block also seems to be blocking off a logical step, would be a good candidate for an extract method refactor.
Yeah, removed this comment.

Why are constructions being removed from unitsToPlace and added to ppt.
Second, would ppt provide better encapsulation if it provided a method to add constructions rather than exposing a mutable datastructure?
EG:
 ppt.getPlaceUnits().addAll(constructions);

to:
 ppt.addConstructions(constructions); // this method could assert that all units match 'unitIsconstruction'

Essentially the method removes units from unitsToPlace and adds them into the ProPurchaseTerritory structure. The reason for this is that the AI decides how many units to build in a territory but then needs to map them to which factory is actually placing the (mostly only matters for sea territories).
Eventually, I do agree that trying to push this and a few other methods into ProPurchaseTerritory would be best just didn't want to tackle that in this PR. If you look at ProPurchaseTerritory its mostly just a data structure currently and was created to begin grouping some of the data fields together to avoid passing around lots of lists but hasn't really gotten much functionality added into it yet.
These 4 data members seem very related. Have you considered creating a type around it?

Not really. I'd have to think more about this class in general to see if/how it would be best to start breaking it up a bit. Compared to most AI classes though this is probably one of the better ones.
What's the rationale for 0.1?
Want it to be essentially an order of magnitude worse than 1 move units. Don't want to return 0 as this is used to multiply with other values to get a kind of purchase value score for units.
Would you mind adding a comment in code? That is actually a bit more involved than I had expected.
Added.

It's a bit difficult to follow this line. An intermediate variable maybe would help, or adding a Matches for 'notConstruction' to avoid the negate. Have you considered unit testing this method to help document and verify it?
Updated.

Is this comment here because it has to be? I wonder as ValidationUtils seems to be more specific than the comment implies. Second, have you considered using @UtilityClass to avoid the private constructor?
Updated comment. Added that annotation to this class and ProPurchaseUtils.
